metadata.title: Activation of Natural Halloysite Nanotubes by Introducing Lanthanum Oxycarbonate Nanoparticles via Co-calcination for Outstanding Phosphate Removal

sections.text:

COMMUNICATION

Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Received 00th January 20xx, Accepted 00th January 20xx
DOI: 10.1039/x0xx00000x
www.rsc.org/
Activation of Natural Halloysite Nanotubes by Introducing Lanthanum Oxycarbonate Nanoparticles via Co-calcination for Outstanding Phosphate Removal Yanfu Weia,b,+, Peng Yuana,c,+,*, Dong Liua,c, Dusan Losicd, Daoyong Tane, Fanrong Chena,c, Hongchang Liua, Junming Zhoua,c, Peixin Dua,c,Yaran Songa,c
Halloysite nanotube was activated through the co-calcination of halloysite and the precursors of lanthanum oxycarbonate (LO), generating reactive alumina nanoparticles and uniformly anchoring LO nanoparticles to halloysite surfaces. The resulting LO-alumina combination exhibits record-high phosphate adsorption capacity as well as excellence in adsorption selectivity and sewage phosphate removal.
Owing to their controlled functions as building blocks, hybrid nanomaterials have attracted enormous attention in the last decades.1 In particular, high-performance hybrid nanostructures synthesized by coating nanoparticles to porous materials are of great interest for applications in catalysis, energy storage, and environmental remediation.2,3 The components of these hybrid structures can be chosen from a broad range of materials, including nanoparticles (e.g., metals, metal oxides, and metal chalcogenides) and porous substrates (e.g., porous carbons, mesoporous silica, metal–organic frameworks, and porous polymers).4,5 However, despite their promise for advanced applications, their fabrication routes using expensive synthetic supports make them disadvantageous for energy and environment applications where large quantities of these materials are required, making economic viability a key concern. Particularly, for the use as an adsorbent for environmental remediation, the porous support
itself, such as SBA-15 silica and carbon nanotube, is frequently not reactive for adsorption, or its reactivity is shielded by the surface coating,6 largely limiting the actual use of the hybrid nanomaterials.
Here, we propose a new strategy to construct novel, hybrid, nanostructured materials by coupling La-based nanoparticles with a natural, nanosized, inorganic support that is activated through the co-calcination during the synthesis of La-based nanoparticles. The central idea of this strategy is using the heat generated from the synthesis of La-based nanoparticles during co-calcination to transform the initially inert Al component of the inorganic support into highly reactive Al2O3 nanoparticles. Thus, both the La-based nanoparticles and the activated nanoparticles of the support are available for contributing to the targeted adsorption. Halloysite (Al2Si2O5(OH)4·nH2O), a natural aluminosilicate nanotube and denoted “halloysite nanotubes (HNT)”, was selected as the above-mentioned nanosized inorganic support. The advantages of the resulting hybrid nanomaterials are demonstrated by its use for the adsorption of phosphate. Halloysite has a 1-D tubular structure, which consists of siloxane (Si−O−Si) groups on the external surface and a gibbsite-like array of aluminol (Al−OH) on the internal surface.7 The typical size of HNT is approximately 10−100 nm in internal diameter and approximately 30−190 nm in external diameter,8 so it allows for the loading of a variety of guests such as nanoparticles for versatile uses.
Phosphate pollution is a serious environmental problem because it leads to eutrophication and threatens organisms in water ecosystems.9 Adsorption is a promising technology for pollutant control.10,11 Over the past decades, many adsorbents, such as natural and synthetic metal oxides and hydroxides,12 have been explored for the removal of phosphate from waters. Lanthanum oxide and hydroxide were found to be some of the most effective adsorbents for the removal of phosphate because they possess a specific affinity for phosphate.13 Various La-based hybrid adsorbents have been prepared using porous supports, such as carbon nanotubes,14 mesoporous silica,15 polyacrylonitrile nanofiber,16 and magnetic cationic hydrogel,17 a.CAS Key Laboratory of Mineralogy and Metallogeny/Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Mineral Physics and Materials, Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), Guangzhou 510640, China b.Key Laboratory of Theoretical Chemistry of Environment, Ministry of Education; School of Chemistry and Environment, South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510006, China c. University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China d.School of Chemical Engineering, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, South Australia 5005, Australia e. Key Laboratory of Solid Waste Treatment and Resource Recycle, Ministry of Education, Southwest University of Science and Technology, Mianyang 621010, China +These authors contributed equally to this work E-mail: yuanpeng@gig.ac.cn Electronic Supplementary Information (ESI) available: details for the synthesis of LOHNT, phosphate adsorption, and characterizations. See DOI: 10.1039/x0xx00000x

sections.heading: COMMUNICATION Journal Name
sections.text:
2 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
to support the La species that are reactive for phosphate removal. As mentioned previously, the optimized efficiency of these hybrid materials as a whole has not been achieved because the porous supports are not involved in the phosphate adsorption.
Figure 1. Illustration of the nanohybrid for the effective phosphate capture by activating the structural Al of natural halloysite nanotubes by introducing LO nanoparticles through co-calcination.
In this work, HNT was activated during co-calcination with the precursors of LO nanoparticle: La(NO3)3·6H2O and C2H5NO2. Such co-calcination results in the disconnection of the unit layer of HNT, transforming the poorly reactive Al in Al-O octahedron into active nano-sized alumina nanoparticles. Notably, the activation of the HNT occurred at a relatively low temperature (450°C) due to the generation of LO provides extra heat during co-calcination, whereas a similar structural change of HNT normally occurs at beyond 700°C7,18. As schematically presented in Figure 1, the novel hybrid nanostructure makes full use of its components from the following aspects. First of all, the LO nanoparticles were massively and homogeneously anchored onto the internal and external surfaces of HNT, wellutilizing the tubular nanostructure of HNT and its large surface area to achieve a desirable high capacity of LO-loading. Moreover, LO nanoparticles possessed excellent phosphate adsorption capacity, mainly via ion exchange. Concurrently, the active nano-sized alumina nanoparticles in the structure of activated HNT made a considerable contribution to phosphate adsorption. The combined functions of LO and alumina created an outstanding phosphate adsorption capacity. Furthermore, the adsorbent exhibited excellent adsorption selectivity against interfering organic matters and inorganic species and was able to work efficiently in a broad pH range. These features of the hybrid, combined with its low-cost and facile preparation, make the hybrid a promising material for practical phosphate remediation.
High-resolution scanning electron microscope (HR-SEM) shows that the La-based materials coat the external siloxane surface of HNT after the La-coating, whereas the pristine HNT (before coating) has a smooth external surface (exemplified by a single HNT particle; Figure 2a). Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) further indicates that the coating occurred not only at the external surface but also on the internal surface of HNT, thereby partially filling the lumen of the HNT (Figure 2b). Energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping (Figure 2c) verifies the uniform loading of the La-based material at both the external surface and the inner 1-D pore of HNT. The
X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra reflect the grafting of the deposited LO on the halloysite surface through Si−O−La and Al−O−La bonding [Figure S1, Supporting Information (SI)]. This LO layer serves as a base for further loading of LO nanoparticles on the external surface; it also allows for the encapsulation of more LO in the 1-D mesoporous channel of HNT. X-ray fluorescence (XRF) quantitative analysis of LO-HNT reveals that the La content accounts for approximately 6.08% of the mole fraction; i.e., 31.39% of the La by mass is anchored on the LO-HNT (Table S1, SI).
The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the hybrid (Figure 2d) show that the main La-species is LO, as indicated by reflections with d-spacing values of 6.76, 3.90, 3.02, 2.90, 2.86, and 2.03 Å corresponding to the (020), (110), (130), (−101), (101), and (200) planes of LO, respectively. The reflection of the LO (130) crystallographic plane can be used to calculate the average diameter (D) of the LO crystallites using the Scherrer equation. The calculated D value of the LO crystallites in the hybrid is 6.6 nm, which confirms the well loading of the LO nanoparticles. The pristine calcined HNT exhibits a typical 7-Å-halloysite XRD pattern (Figure 2d), and the HNT substrate in LO-HNT exhibits a substantially decreased intensity for the main reflections of HNT. This is because the LO reflections are incorporated, and also because the HNT substrate underwent calcination at 450°C, resulting in the partial dehydroxylation of the halloysite substrate.18 The nitrogen absorption-desorption isotherms (Figure 2e) of both LO-HNT and pristine HNT are categorized as type IV isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops.19 This agrees with the 1-D mesoporous structures of both materials. The BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) surface area and the total pore volume values of LO-HNT (29.5 m2/g and 0.11 cm3/g, respectively) are smaller than those of HNT (64.2 m2/g and 0.25 cm3/g). This suggests that the encapsulation of LO into the lumen of HNT decreases the porosity of the materials. The pore size distribution (PSD) curve of HNT shows two distinct pore populations centered near 40 and 15 nm (Figure 2e), corresponding to the lumen size of the HNT and the interparticle pores, respectively. The PSD curve of the hybrid

sections.text:

Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
exhibits a unimodal pore population centered at approximately 25 nm. This decrease of lumen size further indicates the encapsulation of La species in the lumen of HNT.
The activation of HNT after LO-grafting was indicated by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy (Figure S2, SI) and cross-sectional TEM results (Figure S3, SI). Briefly, the vibration bands at 3694, 3626, and 912 cm−1 were assigned to the Al−OH vibrations of HNT20 and were much less distinct in LO-HNT than in HNT. This indicates the occurrence of dehydroxylation and related structural changes in halloysite. Moreover, the hybrid shows a significant weakening of the peaks of Si−O vibrations (at 1089, 1030, 752, 687, and 468 cm−1) and Al−O−Si vibrations (538 cm−1), suggesting a disconnection between tetrahedral SiO4 and octahedral AlO6 in the HNT unit. Thus, there is phase separation of SiO2 and Al2O3, both of which are amorphous nanoparticles.18 These results indicate the cocalcination of HNT and the LO precursors promotes the structural disordering of HNT and results in the production of SiO2 and Al2O3 nanoparticles in LO-HNT. The amorphous nature of the HNT support in the hybrid is further evidenced by its selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Figure S3, inset), showing an isotropic halo. These results demonstrate that the structural disordering of halloysite in the nanohybrid occurs at a much lower temperature (450°C) than the corresponding temperature (approximately 700°C) of pristine halloysite.18
Figure 3. (a) Kinetic studies of LO-HNT (initial phosphate concentration = 700 mg/L, adsorbent dose = 2.5 g/L, 25°C, pH 4.5). (b) Phosphate adsorption isotherms for LO-HNT hybrid nanocomposite (adsorbent dose = 2.5 g/L, 25°C, pH 4.5). (c) Comparison of adsorption capacity between LO-HNT and pure LO nanoparticles. The solid lines in (b) and (c) are the fitted Langmuir adsorption isotherms. (d) The effect of competitive anions and dissolved organic matters on phosphate sequestration by LO-HNT (FA = fulvic acid and HA = humic acid, adsorbent dose = 0.5 g/L, phosphate concentration = 50 mg/L, 25°C, and pH 4.5). (e) Influence of pH on phosphate uptake by LO-HNT (adsorbent dose = 0.5 g/L, phosphate concentration = 50 mg/L, 25°C). (f) Adsorption treatment of a sewage effluent sample with various dose of LO-HNT. Phosphorus concentration of the effluent was 2.3 mg/L.
Figure 4. (a) Schematic of FIB thinning of P@LO-HNT and further structural characterization with (b) TEM, (c) EDS line scan along the yellow dotted line [inset in (b)], and (d) elemental mapping with the signals attributed to different elements: La, P, Si, and Al.
The phosphate adsorption kinetics of LO-HNT show that the adsorption proceeded very quickly, with 80% of the adsorption capacity being attained within 1 h (Figure 3a). The adsorption isotherm data nicely fit the Langmuir model (Figure 3b).
Remarkably, the Langmuir maximum phosphate uptake capacity of LO-HNT reaches 130.4 mg P/g. To the best of our knowledge, this phosphate uptake capacity is the highest among all reported La-coated adsorbents (see details in Table S2). As for normalizing the phosphate adsorption amounts to the La content, the fitted maximum adsorption for LO-HNT reached up to 415.4 mg of P per mg of La, which is a twofold increase compared to LO (Figure 3c). In contrast, the control samples (unheated or calcined HNT at 450 and 700°C) exhibited negligible phosphate adsorption (see Figure S4 and Table S3).
Moreover, the high P-adsorption capacity of LO-HNT was only slightly affected by the presence of dissolved organic matters (humic acid or fulvic acid) or anions such as Cl−, NO3−, HCO3−, and SO42− (Figure 3d) due to the strong affinity between LO (or Al2O3) nanoparticles and phosphate. The P-adsorption capacity of LO-HNT decreased slightly with the increase of the pH within a wide pH range of 3–10. This is attributed to the high isoelectric point of LO and alumina particles (Figure S5), i.e., some of the LO-HNT surfaces were positively charged in a wide pH range and thereby enhanced the electrostatic attraction for phosphate sequestering. In addition, the measurements of the metal leakage of LO-HNT show that the released La3+ and Al3+ concentrations were 1.4 ±0.2 and 71.0 ±0.5 μg/L respectively, within the scope of the metal contents in natural waters (La = 0.006–2.3 μg/L and Al = 2.55–999 μg/L).21 These results imply that LO-HNT is highly stable and has well adaptability to different adsorption conditions, which might be due to the cocalcination treatment allowing the structural stabilization of the hybrid. LO-HNT was further applied as the adsorbent for the removal of phosphate from the domestic sewage effluent (Table S4). Impressively, the residual phosphate concentration decreased to zero when the dose of LO-HNT in sewage effluents was above 0.05 g/L, which is a smaller dosage than that used in the previous phosphate adsorbents (Table S5).
The XPS and FTIR results (SI for details) confirm the synergetic actions of the different components of the hybrid for phosphate adsorption. Partial phosphate adsorption occurs through the effective anionic exchange between the CO32− groups at the (La2O22+)n interlayers of LO in LO-HNT and H2PO4−. Notably, this performance is much better than the pure-phase LO nanoparticles, which show severe aggregation (Figure S6) and are, therefore, less efficient at H2PO4− exchange. In addition to ion exchange adsorption, phosphate adsorption also occurs through surface complexation at both the surface of the coated LO nanoparticles and at the surface of the Al2O3 nanoparticles in LO-HNT. The XPS results confirm the formation of La−O−P bonds and Al−O−P bonds (Figure S1).
Focused ion Beam (FIB) thinning of the sample avoids the influence of the coated La and P on the external surfaces (Figure 4a and 4b) and thereby reveals the state of P occurrence inside the halloysite framework. The line scan analysis confirms the close La-P and Al-P associations (Figure 4c), which are indicated as the number of P atoms being proportional to the number of La and Al atoms. This result further indicates that the Al2O3 nanoparticles in the calcined HNT host contribute to phosphate adsorption. The EDS mapping images (Figure 4d) show the homogeneous distribution of P throughout the inner and outer

sections.heading: COMMUNICATION Journal Name
sections.text:
4 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
surfaces of HNT and the overlapping of the P distribution with La and Al. This is in line with the La-P and Al-P interactions mentioned above. Hence, these results clearly verify the combined phosphate adsorption by the LO and Al2O3 sites of LOHNT.
Phosphorus K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectroscopy was employed to probe the proportion of phosphorus in the phosphate-adsorbed LO-HNT sample (P@LOHNT) by conducting linear combination fitting (LCF) on the XANES spectrum of P@LO-HNT, using the spectra of P@LO and P@Al2O3 as references (Figure 5). The mean square misfit (Rfactor), defined as represents the quality ∑j(dataj - fitj)/∑jdata 2 of the fitting in LCF analysis.22 Generally, the smaller the Rfactor, the better the fit, and an R-factor <0.05 indicates a good fit.22 The obtained R-factor of the LCF analysis is 0.00066, indicating a high-quality fitting. The LCF results show that the proportion of phosphate bonded with LO and Al2O3 in HNT of the hybrid was 76% and 24%, respectively. This result resonates with the coupling of both LO and Al2O3 in LO-HNT in capturing phosphate. XRF (Table S1) and LCF analyses of the P@LO-HNT sample show that of the total P in the sample, 62.6% is from the exchange with CO32− in LO, 13.4% is from the La-complexation on LO surface, and 24% is from the Al-complexation on the Al2O3 surface (detailed in SI). Hence, these analyses offer a clear picture of the three phosphate adsorption mechanisms, i.e., CO32−−H2PO4− exchange of LO loaded at HNT, phosphate complexation with the La species of LO, and phosphate complexation with the Al site of Al2O3 nanoparticles.
Figure 5. Linear combination fitting (LCF) of P XANES spectra of samples: P@LOHNT (the scattering dots), P@LO (the green line), and P@Al2O3 (the red line). The black line represents the resultant spectrum via fitting the spectra of the P@LO and P@Al2O3 references.
In conclusion, we propose here a novel strategy for the preparation of nanohybrid for applications such as adsorption and catalysis. Low-cost halloysite nanotube is used as the substrate of the nanohybrid, and LO is used not only to activate the substrate but to simultaneously serve as active sites for adsorption. For phosphate adsorption, the nanohybrid exhibits a record-high adsorption capacity of 130.4 mg P/g, mainly attributed to the combined adsorption by LO (via anionic exchange and surface complexation) and alumina (via surface complexation), aided by the unique geometry of the HNT nanostructure. The material shows excellent applicability to solutions of various pHs and with co-existing anions and shows good performance at low doses for removing phosphate from actual sewage effluent. The established strategy offers significant promise for contaminant capture and is also applicable for a wide range of functional nanomaterials, acting as a generic platform for potential applications.
This work is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant Nos. 41472045, 41672042, and 41603118), Youth Innovation Promotion Association CAS for the excellent members (Grant No.2016-81-01), the CAS President's International Fellowship Initiative for Visiting Scientists (Grant No. 2017VEA0009), and the Open Funds of the Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (No. 2017-BEPC-PT-001052 and 2017-BEPC-PT-001065). This is a contribution from the GIGCAS.
